abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings show an unsatisfactory project
            outcome, unlikely sustainability, and unsatisfactory
            performances by the Bank and Borrower; yet, institutional
            development impacts were modest. Among the many lessons
            learned, main suggestions are as follows. Deficiencies in
            initial project design can not be easily remedied midway
            through implementation, unless effective restructuring is
            undertaken: The most fundamental lesson from implementation
            of this project is a very basic one, applicable to all
            projects irrespective of sector or region: the importance of
            project design can never be underestimated. Analytic sector
            work would have highlighted many of the deficiencies in
            project design, especially in identifying priority
            challenges that needed to be tackled first in the worst off
            regions. Another more specific lesson that arises from this
            project is that efforts to revise a project that had
            significantly flawed, original design requires more drastic
            action than minor revisions and intensive supervision. The
            Bank needs to adopt a culture where statements of expected
            project impact are more realistic: the project development
            objective responded very clearly to the needs of the country
            at that time. However, part of the failure of the project to
            have any measurable impact, rests squarely on the fact that
            the project over promised in its statement of expected
            impact on major health indicators, by the end of project
            implementation. The expected project impact should have been
            stated more modestly, particularly taking into account the
            fact that there are other important determinants of health
            outcomes, not being addressed by this particular project.
            Further lessons address a) attention to recommendations from
            reviews of design quality; b) maintaining a dialogue on
            global good practices in the midst of unsatisfactory
            implementation; and, c) the role of project coordination
            units in assisting Borrowers to produce sustainable, and
            appropriate outputs needs careful evaluation.

repnme.cdata!:
Turkey - Second Health Project : Essential
            Health Services and Management Development in Eastern and
            Southeastern Anatolia

abstracts.cdata!:
The Second Health Project : Essential
            Health Services and Management Development in Eastern and
            Southeastern Anatolia will provide fellowships, training,
            technical assistance, studies, health programs, computer
            hardware and software, medical and office furniture,
            equipment, vehicles, teaching materials, civil works and
            non-salary incremental recurrent costs. The project, which
            covers 16 percent of Turkey's total population (11.8
            million people in 1993) and 29 percent of its surface area,
            will be implemented over seven and half years through the
            following components: (a) primary health; and (b) health
            policy and management.
